title: Between 18 June 2021 and 18 July 2021, will protests in Peru result in any fatalities?
preds: Two days until closing date with the country still waiting for an official announcement. The country is also severely hampered by corona virus restrictions. The inauguration is scheduled for July 28 with garda.com suggesting operations by the security forces then. https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/502571/peru-further-protests-over-disputed-election-result-likely-nationwide-through-late-july-update-2  https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/perus-castillo-set-be-confirmed-election-winner-right-wing-challenge-founders-2021-07-14/  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/7/11/peru-extends-covid-state-of-emergency-until-end-of-august
Nothing is certain, but I’d put probability for next two days at 1/200, less than 1 percent

Sticking with my forecast as only a few days left but things seem to be getting more desperate in Peru.
A Wednesday demonstration attacked members of Parliament, a journalist and public. Police needed to use force to stop them storming government buildings. My forecast is in a risky position I think.
"Keiko Fujimori after attack on Ministers of Health and Housing: "I reject these attitudes and publicly condemn them" Popular Force Oscar Ugarte Solangel Fernandez nndc | POLICY | THE PERU COMMERCE" https://elcomercio.pe/politica/elecciones/keiko-fujimori-tras-ataque-a-ministros-de-salud-y-vivienda-rechazo-esas-actitudes-y-las-condeno-publicamente-fuerza-popular-oscar-ugarte-solangel-fernandez-nndc-noticia/?ref=ecr/

@msumi Until now we didn't see any reports of fatalities and harsh security forces response towards the protestors. President from the 06 June run-off elections is still not declared by the electoral authorities. If the decision is delayed further, this will raise the risks of widespread protests out of discontent and security forces harsh response is likely in month of August which will result in some fatalities, injuries and arrest.

The extended time for the commission to announce a result has either increased people’s frustration or exhaustion over the process.
The monitors and polls have stated the election to have been free and fair with Castillo the victor. Fujimori has disputed the claims and all her challenges to be processed.
Gardaworld is suggesting security forces may become embroiled in demonstrations and clashes between rival groups.
Supporters of both camps have been organising rival rallies with the inauguration scheduled for July 28.
While there is contention and a slim chance, it is presumed neither party will concede to allow a peaceable transition and not helped by rumours of a military coup if the left-wing Castillo is successful over the right-wing Fujimori.
The democratic rule of Peru is only two decades old having had four Presidents and two parliaments in five years.
Unpredictable, but no violent deaths (yet). https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/peru-wants-president-thousands-march-lima-election-result-drags-2021-07-07/  https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/500211/peru-protests-related-to-disputed-election-outcome-likely-through-mid-july-demonstration-in-lima-july-10-update-1  https://indianexpress.com/article/explained/explained-the-protests-over-presidential-election-results-in-peru-7395701/
Delay in announcing makes any escalation unlikely
A bit late in adjusting, but the time decay -> 5% to 2%.
Great find by @GMR that the election winner won't be announced until after the expiration of this question. That makes it extremely unlikely we'll see  intense protests in the next few days

The JNE is not expecting to announce the winner until the 19th or 20th which is a good thing for our question. The original date of the 16th had me lingering at 97% but will go to 99 now. Nothing is certain but I don't suspect that points for 99% wrong would hurt any less than 100% wrong. So might just hit the big time.
"Proclamation of results is delayed due to delay of votes in minority of Víctor Rodríguez Monteza | JNE | Pedro Castillo | Keiko Fujimori | Elections 2021 | ELECTIONS-2021 | THE PERU COMMERCE" https://elcomercio.pe/elecciones-2021/proclamacion-de-resultados-se-retrasa-por-demora-de-votos-en-minoria-de-victor-rodriguez-monteza-jne-pedro-castillo-keiko-fujimori-elecciones-2021-noticia/?ref=signwall
Not out of the woods yet but things seem stable and some great comments have already been made in support of upping the no response

Sat seemed quiet in Lima. 
Private motor vehicles are banned on Sunday. Which will empty the streets for demonstrations 
But more importantly allow focus on a mass vaccination event for the country "Gobierno inicia vacunación masiva sábado y domingo" https://elperuano.pe/noticia/124327-gobierno-inicia-vacunacion-masiva-sabado-y-domingo
Police have announce a major plan for public safety to ensure that vaccinations run smoothly "Bicentenario: 106 mil agentes policiales brindarán seguridad durante Fiestas Patrias" https://elperuano.pe/noticia/124365-bicentenario-106-mil-agentes-policiales-brindaran-seguridad-durante-fiestas-patrias The police have called on politicians not to promote any mobilisation or demonstration to assist in the vaccination drive. 
"Elice: No permitiremos que el proceso de vacunación se vea afectado por alguna movilización" https://elperuano.pe/noticia/124360-elice-no-permitiremos-que-el-proceso-de-vacunacion-se-vea-afectado-por-alguna-movilizacion The govt is preparing for a peaceful transition.
"Bermúdez: Gobierno ha sido absolutamente neutral durante el proceso de elecciones" https://elperuano.pe/noticia/124356-bermudez-gobierno-ha-sido-absolutamente-neutral-durante-el-proceso-de-elecciones However, even with Police persuassion to stop the demonstrations, Fuerza Popular held a 'mobilisation' that ended with Fujimori again calling for her followers to fight the corruption. Police in riot gear were in attendance but things remained peaceful.
https://elcomercio.pe/politica/elecciones/keiko-fujimori-jne-van-a-consumar-el-fraude-en-la-mesa-y-nosotros-no-vamos-a-aceptarlo-pedro-castillo-peru-libre-elecciones-2021-segunda-vuelta-nndc-noticia/
I'm not sure the winner will even be announced by July 18th

Police are keeping rival demonstrations apart. Both side say they are ready to 'fight' but is that in the streets or in the courts?
As long as they don't announce a winner this weekend I think it will stay positive and peaceful. 
Once a winner is announced all bets are off.
Only 2 weekends to go til question closes

I made this forecast and then looked at some of the activity -- and I think @rgao summed it up pretty perfectly. As he said -- this isn't a new issue, and particularly with only ~10 days left until July 18, it would have to escalate pretty significantly in a short amount of time. Even if we assume a greater base rate than we see from prev. fatalities -- still yields a < 1 % chance of > 50 fatalities

Peru has been in a period of political crisis and instability since 2017, and has seen a number of large-scale political protests, at least 6 of which are documented on Wikipedia. Only one of these protests has resulted in a fatality. Any would-be political protests occurring before 18 July are likely to be smaller in scale, given the most likely trigger is Peru's narrowly contested recent presidential election. Then we can estimate an "adjusted" number of protests as ~20, and so the base rate of protest fatalities would be 1/20. In terms of non-political protests in Peru, since 2009 there have been 5 notable events, with 4 resulting in fatalities. We estimate the probability of one of these events occurring prior to 18 July as (11 days)/((12 years)(365 days/year)) * 5 = 1.26%. Then apply a 4/5 = 80% fatality probability, with almost certain probability of less than 20 fatalities.
Likely not. But 1 or some - possible. Some people may just die from overheat during the protest, that would also count as a fatality
passage of time and I believe too much credence given to bins 3/4 given historical data https://acleddata.com/dashboard/#/dashboard

Protests in the country over varying reasons is common, however, protests in the past remain peaceful and security forces remain restraint to use harsh response. President elections run off results are not announced until yet and no deadline is scheduled.
things will cool down in the south. but only for a short while and the blood will flow unlike ever seen. big change coming and the people will force feed.

"Al Jazeera’s Mariana Sanchez, reporting from Lima, said “the situation is very tense” amid the duelling rallies of Fujimori and Castillo supporters in the capital. “It’s been 20 days [since the election] and still no official results yet,” she said, adding that police are trying to keep the rival groups apart." https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/6/26/peru-vote-review-to-resume-as-country-braces-for-protests I'm nudging down as some time has passed but we're not out of the woods yet
One is likely an activist or an anarchist.

Catholic church has called on people to let democracy prevail. They have a lot of power in peru with between 75 and 85% of people being catholic. "AMERICA/PERU - The Bishops: "the Church believes in democracy, defends the democratic system, supports the electoral results" - Agenzia Fides" http://www.fides.org/en/news/70403-AMERICA_PERU_The_Bishops_the_Church_believes_in_democracy_defends_the_democratic_system_supports_the_electoral_results
Seems like delays might be possible, which could lead to unrest but this is more likely after our question period in my opinion. I expect the major protests will be on independence day and inauguration day. I would give a higher probability of deaths if the period included the 28th. 
I would like to look at the outside chance. What has happened between election and inauguration of other South American states
Would be higher for 0 but deep polarisation makes precedent slightly less valuable

Much of my thinking on this question has been influenced by the ALCED resource and discussion with @cafebedouin who assigns an extremely low probability (~ 0%) for any casualties. I differ slightly (~ 5%) for one reason - we often see autocorrelation in social phenomena over short time horizons. While it's true that the base rate is extremely low, its recency is relevant and some of the pre-conditions for violence seems to be there (close election, global media looking for its fix etc)...
More likely than not, there will be an attributable death due to protests. It's more of an inevitable issue than anything else.
The protests seem relatively peaceful, so I don't think there will be many, if any, fatalities.
The Street finds its own uses for things.

what a complicated situation!
Pedro Castillo (school teacher) has narrowly won election (50.12%) of vote
Peru's beaten right wing candidate Fujimori (daughter of jailed ex president Alberto Fujimori) has alleged fraud and is seeking to overturn votes in Castillos supporting area. International observers say no evidence of fraud. lots of money behind Fujimori so some very high paid lawyers working her side.
Fujimoris supporters vowing to support her. This suggests there will definitely be protests but will they result in death?
There has been a lot of unrest in Peru over the last 4 years (apparently 10 different periods of unrest)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017%E2%80%93present_Peruvian_political_crisis Castillo has promised a smooth transition but wants to reform constitution and tax mines higher which is concerning right.
https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/perus-electoral-board-says-it-is-working-top-speed-resolve-election-questions-2021-06-17/ Retired military has written a letter suggesting current military refuse to recognise Castillo if he is sworn in.
https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/peru-ex-military-stir-election-tensions-with-appeal-armed-forces-remedy-poll-2021-06-18/ the guardian makes claims of elitism and racial discrimination by right.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jun/20/peru-elite-election-pedro-castillo-keiko-fujimori Over the last 20 years:
last years protests were quite extensive and resulted in 2 deaths (but 40 missing). other protest deaths occurred in 2009, resulting in around 50 deaths. it is hard to find solid info but it looks like 5 protestors died in 2012.
it looks like the base rate for protests is quite high, while the base rate for deaths as a result of protests is 3 times over the last 20 years ( 15% ish)

International observers are reporting that there is no evidence of voter fraud with the pollster Ipsos Peru stating it has no evidence of abnormal voting trends. The Electoral Observation Mission of the Organization of American States declared in a preliminary report, that there was a ‘positive electoral process’ with no detection of any serious irregularities. Observers form the Inter-American Union of Electoral Organizations, (UNIORE) commended the National Election Board (JNE) for a ‘correctly organized and successful’ election, according to the JNE president.
The election on June 6 gave Pedro Castillo 50.125 % with Keiko Fujimori on 49.875% of the vote, giving a difference of 44.058 votes from 18.8 million cast.
Fujimori has challenged the result with charges of electoral fraud and there can be no transition of power until these have been resolved.
Demonstrations and counter demonstrations have been held peaceably so far.
The divisions are between the urban coastal areas and the rural highlands that include wealth and ethnic divides.
Michelle Bachelet the United Nations high commissioner for human rights has issued a statement condemning hate speech and discrimination and urging an acceptance of the result.
Given the official recognition of the electoral process and result and the level of peaceful protests so far, extreme violence resulting in fatalities would only become a reality if the result was overturned by a coup (as suggested by a group of ex-army officers). https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/6/20/rival-protests-in-peru-as-tensions-rise-over-presidential-vote
https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/peru-ex-military-stir-election-tensions-with-appeal-armed-forces-remedy-poll-2021-06-18/
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/6/18/who-is-pedro-castillo-perus-presumed-president-elect
https://www.dw.com/en/peru-elections-leftist-castillo-claims-election-victory-despite-right-wing-pushback/a-57914494
https://www.wilsoncenter.org/blog-post/peru-edge-following-polarizing-close-election  https://www.cfr.org/in-brief/will-perus-polarized-election-bring-more-instability  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/6/12/perus-castillo-on-verge-of-winning-presidency-after-tight-race  https://www.peruviantimes.com/08/virtual-tie-in-castillo-fujimori-election-results-leads-to-call-of-fraud/32386/
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jun/07/peru-elections-results-pedro-castillo-keiko-fujimori
https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-06-08/socialist-castillo-holds-slim-lead-as-peru-presidential-vote-count-reaches-tense-finale  https://thewire.in/world/peru-has-a-choice-democracy-or-a-return-to-dictatorship
Using ACCLED data per @cafebedouin definitely lowered my estimates for >10 and for 1-10.

This is ACLED data. Doing the last twenty years there has been 2 fatalities in 2335 protests. So, that's > 1 in 1,000 or 0% for our purposes.
https://acleddata.com/dashboard/#/dashboard

"Peru says that its Covid-19 death toll is almost three times as high as it had officially counted until now, making it one of the hardest-hit nations relative to its population."  https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/05/31/world/covid-vaccine-coronavirus-mask "In reference to the mobilizations planned for today, the Government official stated that no demonstrations should be held due to the risks posed by the COVID-19 pandemic." https://andina.pe/Ingles/noticia-perus-pm-executive-branch-will-not-tolerate-disrespect-to-armed-forces-849851.aspx "According to the official vote count, Castillo has a razor-thin lead of 40,000 votes out of the 18.8 million cast, but cannot be officially declared president-elect until Fujimori’s challenges are resolved — a process that could take weeks." (Swearing in isn't until July 28)
"[Fujimori] is facing a trial of her own, for allegedly laundering $17m and a potentially lengthy jail sentence — unless she acquires presidential immunity."
"Fujimori’s supporters have picketed the homes of the head of the Andean nation’s electoral agency and members of the JNE, the electoral tribunal tasked with resolving her appeals. They have also launched a tsunami of often racially-tinged social media attacks against Castillo’s allies, journalists and anyone else questioning Fujimori’s hardball tactics, accusing them of being “communist” and even “terrorists”."
"Police officers set up cordons between supporters of the two candidates to prevent clashes."
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/6/18/who-is-pedro-castillo-perus-presumed-president-elect There are obviously high tensions, and the authorities are aware and actively trying to prevent altercations. Sorting through the challenges to the vote will likely mean a calm before the storm that will almost inevitably happen when it's made official, regardless of the outcome. The question of fatalities is challenging though. There will almost certainly be injuries. Authorities may be more hesitant to use rubber bullets after last years events. There is also a risk of major escalation if deaths are directly caused by supporters on one side against supporters of the the other. I'll be an optimist initially but will have to pay attention to this one
Three dead in 2020 protests but a pretty big backlash:  https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Peruvian_protests

Chance of demonstrations High
Chance of growing to protests Med
Chance of Growing to riots Low-med
Chance of deaths in a police clash low
I found it hard to choose a base rate for this compound question
Will monitor election outcome and any changes in public mood
Will increase probabilities with more protests and decrease it with time.
I have allowed my death forecast to increase because of the crowd position
somewhat skeptical of the no fatalities option as policing and protesting have turned to more violent tactics.

I think it's more like 20% instead of the crowd's 30%. Protests haven't really started yet, other than Keiko supporters doing some "stop the count" rallies. Castillo won, 100% of the votes have been counted, and they're going through the "muh-election-was-rigged" phase that apparently happens whenever a presidential candidate loses a close election these days. That doesn't translate automatically into mass, violent protests, however.

Police brutality has been denounced in previous demonstrations in Peru, such as last December, when there were two casualties but several wounded. This time around demonstrations between the supporters of Keiko Fujimori and of the elected socialist president will likely last long and will be met with violence by the police with the use of lead pellets or glass marbles until a final verdict on the validity of elections will be issued by the court and until the new president will be sworn in.

Tensions are certainly high in Peru but I do believe they'll want to do everything possible to keep it peaceful considering 2020.  Currently one candidate won't admit defeat to the progressive winner.  Will monitor closely.  Could see it escalating. I put likelihood of something happening at around 1/3 and distributed that more towards 1-10, although tried to keep relatively even beyond that.

Looked to history but also mindful that many deadly protests in Peru were not related to elections, but when they do, they tend to happen very quickly so it seems plausible that many deaths are to come within this hot election month. There was a protest a few years ago about women's rights and because Ms. Fujimori, a woman, is not conceding, this may trigger backlash. Then again, I presume most of her supporters are women and women tend to be less violent than men. Perhaps the men are glad she lost and won't have the urge to throw a rock. Sexist perspective here. This is concerning, though: At least 14 killed in Peru attack before presidential election https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/5/24/deadly-peru-attack-just-weeks-before-election
